title: Jack Reilly (footballer)
text:
John Reilly (born 27 August 1943) is a former <a href="association%20football">football</a> <a href="Goalkeeper%20%28association%20football%29">goalkeeper</a> who was a member of the <a href="Australia%20national%20soccer%20team">Australia national soccer team</a>, representing the nation 35 times during the 1970s; he was in the <a href="1974%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1974 FIFA World Cup</a> squad and also represented <a href="Victoria%20%28Australia%29">Victoria</a>.
Career.
Reilly learnt his goalkeeping skills while playing with local <a href="Aberdeenshire">Aberdeenshire</a> <a href="Scottish%20Junior%20Football%20Association">Junior</a> sides <a href="Parkvale%20F.C.">Parkvale</a>, in his hometown of Stonehaven, and <a href="Inverurie%20Loco%20Works%20F.C.">Inverurie Loco Works</a>, prior to moving to the <a href="reserve%20team">reserve team</a> of <a href="Hibernian%20F.C.">Hibernian</a>. He made only two first appearances in the <a href="Scottish%20Football%20League">Scottish Football League</a> before moving to American club <a href="Washington%20Whips">Washington Whips</a> in 1968. Reilly moved to Australia in 1970, signing with Melbourne Juventus. After showing immense talent during his debut season he was drafted into the <a href="Australia%20national%20soccer%20team">Australia</a> squad for a world tour. His transfer from <a href="St%20George%20FC">St George Saints</a> to <a href="Melbourne%20Hakoah">Melbourne Hakoah</a> in early 1972 was a then record fee for a goalkeeper of $6,000.
Reilly continued to represent Australia and was selected for their <a href="1974%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1974 FIFA World Cup</a> squad. He played in all of their three matches at the tournament, against <a href="West%20Germany%20national%20football%20team">West Germany</a>, <a href="East%20Germany%20national%20football%20team">East Germany</a> and <a href="Chile%20national%20football%20team">Chile</a>. Reilly transferred to Fitzroy United <a href="Heidelberg%20United">Heidelberg United</a> in 1975. He spent two season at Fitzroy before transferring to South Melbourne. Reilly retired from playing in 1980.
After ending his playing career, Reilly became a <a href="horse%20breeder">horse breeder</a>. He has also served on the committees of <a href="Football%20Federation%20Australia">FFA</a> and <a href="FIFA">FIFA</a>.
